CommentEng: Despite the fact that dancing has long been regarded as an integral part of Persian history and culture, Islamic law in Iran has criminalized dancing as a means of spreading depravity.
German: Für das Tanzen auf der Straße

commentEng: It is illegal in Iran for couples to hug, kiss, hold hands, or engage in any other public displays of affection.
French: Pour avoir peur lors de s'embrasser
German: Für die Angst sich zu küssen

English: For my sister, your sister, our sisters
French: Pour ma sœur, ta sœur, nos sœurs
German: Für meine Schwester, deine Schwester und unseren Schwestern

French: Pour changer les cerveaux qui ont pourri
Pour avoir honte, pour n'avoir pas d'argent
German: Für die Scham, für die Armut

English: For yearning for a normal life
French: Pour le regret d'une vie ordinaire
German: Für die Sehnsucht nach einem normalen Leben

English: For the waste picker child and his dreams
commentEng:
This tweet refers to an interview with a child labourer in which the interviewer asks the child “what job do you want to have in the future?” He answers that he wants to be a waste picker. The interviewer asks: “what is your dream?” and he answers: “What’s a dream?” 
The video went viral with the title “the child who didn’t know what is a dream”.
French: Pour l'enfant poubelle et ses rêves
German: Für ein Kind, das im Müll wühlt und seine Träume

commentEng: This tweet refers to Ali Khamenei's frequent comments on the resistance economy during hard times, as well as his price-controlling strategies and excessive government interference in the economy.

In many Iranian cities, dangerously high levels of air pollution have been caused by a variety of factors, including poor management of the country's natural resources. Tehran, the capital of Iran, is frequently listed as one of the world's most polluted cities.

English: For Valiasr Street, and its dying trees
commentEng:
Valiasr Street, formerly known as Pahlavi Street, is a 17.9 km (11.1 mi) long street in Tehran, Iran, that is well-known for its tall plane trees. It is regarded as one of Tehran's main thoroughfares and commercial districts. 
The gradual disappearance of the historic plane trees that give the street its character has drawn criticism. Only 8,000 of the 18,000 trees that were once there are still standing; the others have been destroyed.

English: For Pirouz and the possibility of its extinction
commentEng: Pirouz is an Asiatic cheetah (Acinonyx jubatus venaticus), a critically endangered cheetah subspecies currently only surviving in Iran. Read more on Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asiatic_cheetah
French: Pour Pirouz (guépard persan) et sa possible extinction
German: Für den Pirouz und sein mögliches Aussterben

commentEng: Animal cruelty is not a crime in Iran, and despite fierce criticism, municipalities in Iran have taken violent measures to reduce the number of stray dogs. There have been numerous reports of municipal officials directly shooting dogs, injecting them with acid, burying them in lime, and using other extermination techniques, which have sparked outrage and protests from animal rights organizations.

English: For the image of "repeating this moment"
commentEng: The tweet is in reference to those killed in the shooting down of flight PS752 by the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) shortly after takeoff, which resulted in the deaths of all 176 on board, including the crew. The tweet reads, "For Hamed Esmaeilion, that will never be able to repeat this moment again," and features a picture of Hamed Esmaeilion reading the newspaper with his daughter Reera. Reera Esmaeilion and her mother Parisa Eghbalian, were among victims of the flight PS752.
French: Pour l'image répétée de ce moment
German: Für die Wiederholung solcher Momente und Bilder

commentEng: The tweet makes reference to the fact that many Iranians have chosen not to set their photos as profile pictures in order to remain anonymous to the government, saying, "For the day when all of our profiles are our own photos with smiling faces." Out of concern for the repercussions, many women have also been reluctant to post a profile photo without a hijab.

German: Für die Studierenden, für die Zukunft

commentEng: The tweet makes reference to a number of rules and laws that the Islamic government established for theological reasons, such as the hijab requirement or alcohol ban, to safeguard its citizens from sin.

German: Für diejenigen, die im Gefängnis sind

commentEng: The Iranian government has applied numerous discriminatory laws to Afghan immigrants and asylum seekers in the areas of employment, education, insurance, and other issues. Afghan children, for instance, frequently struggle to get accepted into schools. Afghans are also prohibited from enrolling in a number of university academic programs.

Persian: برای این همه شعارهای تو خالی
commentEng: "For all the death slogans that you forced the pupils to chant, and then you suppressed the same children with bullets," reads the tweet, which appears to be referring to the required chants of "death to America" and "death to Israel" for students in schools.

English: For the rubbles of flimsy houses
commentEng: The tweet refers to organizational corruption and bribery in government urban development organizations that have caused subpar and unstable housing and even building collapses. It also specifically refers to the collapse of the Abadan Metropol building, which caused 37 injuries and 43 fatalities.
French: Pour la ruine de fausses maisons
German: Für den Schutt der billig gebauten Häuser

Persian: برای خورشید پس از شبای طولانی
English: For the sun after long nights
French: Pour le soleil après de longues nuits
German: Für die Sonne nach langen Nächten

English: For the antidepressant pills and insomnia
French: Pour les sédatives et les hypnotiques
Pour l'homme, la patrie, le développement
German: Für den Mensch, das Heimatland und die Ortschaft

Persian: برای دختری که آرزو داشت پسر بود
English: For a girl who wished she was a boy
commentEng:
It has been suggested that this tweet might refer to the death of Sahar Khodayari, also known as Blue Girl. She was an Iranian soccer fan who tried to break the country's ban on women attending sporting events by posing as a man and entering the Azadi Stadium to watch her favorite team play. 
She was detained, and the Islamic Revolutionary Court of Tehran informed her in court that she might receive a six-month prison sentence. After leaving court, she committed suicide through self-immolation in front of the building.
French: Pour une fille qui souhaitait être fils
German: Für das Mädchen, das sich wünschte ein Junge zu sein
